column1: Responding to stress in the way described above is a very positive thing. In fact
column2: it is essential. Without a stress response
column3: the T. Rex would probably eat us. But
column5: how many times in most of our lives are we stressed because a T. Rex (or any predator
column6: for that matter) is going to eat us? We are much more likely to be stressed by ongoing non-physical worries. Social relationships
column7: performance in school or at work
column8: the unknown of trying something new; these are the things that are likely to stress us on a daily basis. These are also situations in which an increased heart rate or more blood flow to your muscles are not particularly useful at all. In these cases
column9: known as chronic stress (because it lasts for a long time)
column10: the stress response can actually be very bad for you.
